text:
Hey all,

Has anyone here successfully implemented/managed relatively big content clusters where the general topics are quite close to each other? (Topics like email marketing, marketing automation, lead generation, etc. on a blog of ca. 1k posts)

Got two things I'm uncertain about (internal linking related) and would love to chat about them.

_Q1. Assuming a product feature page is our money page, do you link back to that page from just the pillar article or also from content cluster articles? (Our previous SEO-guy was all about the first option, but it's counterintuitive for me)_

_Q2. Within the whole cluster (including the pillar article), do you only link back to the one single feature page (and stay away from linking to other feature pages?). Our features are strongly related - forms, landing pages, facebook ads, webinars, email marketing, marketing automation, etc. It seems natural to link to other feature pages & sometimes to other articles outside of the cluster._

elements.text:
Hey all,

Has anyone here successfully implemented/managed relatively big content clusters where the general topics are quite close to each other? (Topics like email marketing, marketing automation, lead generation, etc. on a blog of ca. 1k posts)

Got two things I'm uncertain about (internal linking related) and would love to chat about them.

Q1. Assuming a product feature page is our money page, do you link back to that page from just the pillar article or also from content cluster articles? (Our previous SEO-guy was all about the first option, but it's counterintuitive for me)

Q2. Within the whole cluster (including the pillar article), do you only link back to the one single feature page (and stay away from linking to other feature pages?). Our features are strongly related - forms, landing pages, facebook ads, webinars, email marketing, marketing automation, etc. It seems natural to link to other feature pages & sometimes to other articles outside of the cluster.

text:
<@UUXMCJQ15> 
Quick intro, no BS, always educational, and lots of nice formatting with headers, numbers, and bullet points

elements.text: Quick intro, no BS, always educational, and lots of nice formatting with headers, numbers, and bullet points

text:
TO answer you questions directly.

1. That's silly to only link to it from pillar pages. Link whenever it makes sense. Linking across clusters should ABSOLUTELY happen (again, when it makes sense). IF you're talking about marketing automation, would you ignore email marketing? That's a pretty big part of it for most folks.
2. When I link to feature pages, I try to monitor the anchor text (the words that are in the link) and go from there. They don't need to always match, but internal linking is how we got Allstate Insurance to rank #1 for car insurance. It's pretty powerful if you have a lot of authority already. We didn't pay attention to clusters and instead focused on everywhere on the site that we were already using phrases like "car insurance" and "auto insurance" in the content.

elements.text: TO answer you questions directly.

That's silly to only link to it from pillar pages. Link whenever it makes sense. Linking across clusters should ABSOLUTELY happen (again, when it makes sense). IF you're talking about marketing automation, would you ignore email marketing? That's a pretty big part of it for most folks.

When I link to feature pages, I try to monitor the anchor text (the words that are in the link) and go from there. They don't need to always match, but internal linking is how we got Allstate Insurance to rank #1 for car insurance. It's pretty powerful if you have a lot of authority already. We didn't pay attention to clusters and instead focused on everywhere on the site that we were already using phrases like "car insurance" and "auto insurance" in the content.

text: This is great, <@UUXMCJQ15>. Thanks a lot! That's what I thought, but our previous SEO-person was v. strict about linking only within a particular cluster. He wanted to pass all the link equity from cluster pieces to the pillar page and then from the pillar page to the feature/money-page. Which in our situation meant that we're often mentioning a feature but not linking to it from cluster pieces.

Which in our situation meant that we're often mentioning a feature but not linking to it from cluster pieces.

text:
<@UQ3Q7SQ6A> a quick and dirty way of finding relevant links on your site to use for internally linking (we do this often and it works well):

Use the site:search operator in Google, and search your site for the main topics you want to cross-link.

Put this in your URL bar: “site:<http://www.getresponse.com|www.getresponse.com> email marketing”

It’ll turn up what Google thinks are all the relevant pages are for “email marketing” on a single domain. Similar to looking up what queries are driving traffic to specific pages in your GSC.

Then use those URLs as internal linking opportunities, if relevant.

Edit: more on this <https://www.semrush.com/blog/google-search-operators/|here>. See “How to Find Internal Linking Opportunities Using Google Search Operators”

Use the site:search operator in Google, and search your site for the main topics you want to cross-link.

It’ll turn up what Google thinks are all the relevant pages are for “email marketing” on a single domain. Similar to looking up what queries are driving traffic to specific pages in your GSC.

Then use those URLs as internal linking opportunities, if relevant.

text:
+1 for what <@UUXMCJQ15> said

Also, that Sitebulb graph only shows one link relationship, I’m guessing the first. So this only shows part of your internal link structure. What you want to see are all the relationships between pages. I’m not aware of a tool that does this.

said
